Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Multidisciplinary Physics at Purdue University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) and Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) site will provide 12 undergraduate physics majors from across the country with a ten-week long genuine research project emphasizing one-to-one mentoring with faculty from a wide range of disciplines within the Purdue University Department of Physics. Interactions with the community of scientists is emphasized with a interdisciplinary science seminar series, two required public talks on their research, a poster at a general Purdue-wide undergraduate research conference, tours of Purdue scientific facilities including the unique Brick nanotechnology center, field trips to national facilities at Fermilab and Argonne, and the REU Olympics at Notre Dame University, plus various social activities. The weekly seminar initiated and hosted by Physics Department combines Physics REU participants with students from other Purdue summer sites (REU & SURF at Biology, Chemistry, Engineering etc.) to emphasize interdisciplinary opportunities and interactions among students across many fields. Similar objectives are desired for two RET participants, whose research activities will be reflected in their subsequent classroom teaching, inspiring their own students about careers in research.

The participants in this REU and RET program will collaborate with their mentors and other researchers to advance diverse state-of-the-art areas of physics, such as: nanophysics of electrons in reduced dimensional conductors, the dynamical behavior in proteins, the quantum mechanisms of photosynthesis, single molecule/protein dynamic imaging, the use of cosmogenic nuclei as chronometers in geoscience, coherent imaging of tumors, particle detectors with improved hardness and resolution, detectors for TeV radiation, investigation of dark matter, novel application of nuclear detectors for sensing hazardous materials, properties of graphene, applications of biofilms in seismic measurements, the fundamental nature of nuclear decay, enhanced long-baseline imaging for radio astronomy, seismic propagation in structures of geologic interest, the quantum nature of bird magnetoreception, analysis of data collected by scientists at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and other current topics of importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary:

The project was a continuation of REU program "REU Site: Multidisciplinary Physics at Purdue University" and recruited 12 undergaduate students from across the country in summer 2018 to work on various research projects.

Intellectual merit:

Twelve participants were selected from about 300 applicants to work on research projects in the Department of Physics and Astronomy, Purdue University. The individual projects covered a number of cutting-edge topics;the abstracts of all projects are accessible to public through Purdue REU web site (http://www.physics.purdue.edu/research/reu) under Research Projects link. In spite of short program duration (10 weeks), two publications have already resulted from that research with the participating REU students (D Murphy and CJ Riggert):

* Teng Bian,Daniel Murphy, Rongxin Xia, Ammar Daskin, Sabre Kais (2018). Comparison study of quantum computing methods for simulating the Hamiltonian of the water molecule.  arXiv preprint. arXiv:1

* Alarcon, Miguel A., Colin J. Riggert, and Francis Robicheaux. "Simulations of Majorana spin flips in an antihydrogen trap." Journal of Physics B: Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics, 52:155004 (2019).

The program also provided participants with series of research seminars, specialized courses/training, tours to Fermi Lab, Argonne National Laboratory, Notre Dame University, Brick nanotechnology center as well as additional cohort-building social activities such as welcome and farewell parties, canoe trip, REU Olympics.

 Broader impact:

The program target was to recruit a diverse multidisciplinary and yet coherent group of students that mimics the composition of faculty of a modern research institution with an emphasis to involve more participants from underrepresented groups and colleges with limited research opportunities. As the result half of the recruited group were female students and about half of the group were from smaller schools with limited research opportunities. The overal REU program goal is to involve more students from across all groups of people to ensure future progress in  science and technology in the U.S.A.
